profiles:
Summary Material science engineer with background in mechanical and materials testing, experience in electronics manufacturing, and skills in finite-element analysis. Summary Material science engineer with background in mechanical and materials testing, experience in electronics manufacturing, and skills in finite-element analysis. Material science engineer with background in mechanical and materials testing, experience in electronics manufacturing, and skills in finite-element analysis. Material science engineer with background in mechanical and materials testing, experience in electronics manufacturing, and skills in finite-element analysis. Experience Mechanical TD Engineer Intel Corporation April 2002  – Present (13 years 5 months) Hillsboro, OR Responsible for developing core competencies in mechanical metrology and methodology, encompassing both experimental and analytical, to facilitate adoption of new chip packaging and to drive higher interconnect density. 
 
● Assume leadership role in development of FEA and metrology techniques to improve core competency in mechanical capabilities. 
● Leverage capabilities in metrology and analysis to realize cost reduction, to optimize designs, to influence industry through JEDEC/IPC, and to enable new product launch at OEM/ODM partners. 
● Partner with internal development groups to develop new technologies in PCB and PCB assembly, CPU sockets, and sort/test probes. 
● Develop new Monte Carlo analysis tools using Python and Matlab to assess manufacturing robustness of new technologies. 
● Promoted and won numerous awards for consistently innovating new solutions and extracting value from applied R&D. Process Engineer Intel Corporation 1997  –  2002  (5 years) Hillsboro, OR Responsible for developing PCB and electronics assembly processes and delivering manufacturing solutions that meet objectives for throughput, design, total cost, reliability, and assembly ergonomics. 
 
● Use FMEA to prioritize risk, fractional factorial DOE’s to screen for effects, and passive data collection (PDC) to qualify large footprint flip chip package for SMT. 
● Responsible for continuous improvement of wave soldering process. 
● Implemented process monitor and response flow to improve process Cpk and to avoid unnecessary capital expenditure. 
● Create DFM rules to improve assembly yields, quality, and assembly ergonomics. 
● Lead cross-functional teams to drive part cost reductions and launch new assembly processes at HVM sites. 
● Promoted for consistent performance in delivering high quality manufacturing solutions and for recovering schedule of supporting products needed to enable new CPU introduction. Research Assistant Pacific Northwest National Laboratory 1995  –  1997  (2 years) Richland, WA Study the fundamental science of high temperature solid-oxide fuel cells (SOFC). Responsible for creating tools and applying EIS to study of SOFC cathode materials. 
 
● Designed and assembled equipment to accurately measure the electrical conductivity of oxygen conducting solid electrolytes. Integrated data acquisition with temperature control to allow for an automated process 
● Applied electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) to characterize solid oxide cathode performance on zirconia. Identified a previously unrecognized source of experimental error and developed a mitigating solution. Experience Camera hardware Apple March 2015  – Present (6 months) 12 Maskit st., Herzeliya Pituah, Israel Mechanical TD Engineer Intel Corporation September 2011  –  February 2015  (3 years 6 months) Portland, Oregon Area Technology Development MEMS Modeling Engineer Cavendish Kinetics December 2010  –  August 2011  (9 months) San Jose, CA Assistant Project Scientist UC San Diego August 2008  –  July 2010  (2 years) Greater San Diego Area MEMS - Micro Electro Mechanical Systems: RF MEMS. Modeling, design and fabrication of novel electrostatic switches and switched capacitors with low sensitivity to temperature and residual stresses. 
 
• Developed new designs of electrostatic RF MEMS switches and tunable capacitors with very low sensitivity to temperature and residual stresses. 
• Succeeded in building a MEMS tunable capacitor with analog tunability which is very challenging to the inherent mechanical instability of the device under electrostatic actuation. 
• Developed new MEMS capacitive switches with very low temperature-sensitivity. For these devices, the change in the up-state capacitance was < 4% at 25-125C and the change in the pull-in voltage was <100 mV/C. Other designs also exhibit a change in the pull-in voltage of <60 mV/C. These are considered to be one of the most temperature stable RF MEMS devices ever developed. 
• Developed capacitive miniature switch with pull-down and pull-up electrodes for high power applications. Postdoctoral Researcher University of Pennsylvania September 2006  –  July 2008  (1 year 11 months) Philadelphia, PA MEMS - Micro Electro Mechanical Systems: MEMS piezoelectric resonators and switches, Finite element analysis, Analytical dynamics, Microsystem design and fabrication. 
 
• Developed the first piezoelectric Aluminum Nitride (AlN) RF switch which is monolithically integrated with piezoelectric resonators and filters. The switch mechanism is designed in such a way that the device performance is insensitive to residual stresses and ambient temperature. Furthermore, the monolithic integration of the switch and the recently introduced contour-mode resonator technology can significantly affect the design of new RF front-ends by impacting their size, power efficiency and also drastically reducing parasitics and off-state leakage. Such integration will enable new RF architectures based on large arrays of switched multi-frequency AlN contour-mode resonators.  
• Worked on developing a nano-electromechanical piezoelectric switch for logic gate applications. The results was shown that a nano cantilever beam, L =5-18 um, w =2-4 um, t=0.35 um, with an ultra thin piezoelectric layer ~100 nm can be fabricated and actuated with excellent performances. This make the AlN a very promising piezoelectric material for nano-electro-mechanical switches for low power logic applications. Teaching Assistant Technion - Israel Institute of Technology October 2000  –  July 2006  (5 years 10 months) Haifa Teaching Assistant of : 
“Dynamics” 2000 – 2006

• Concentrated on examining the thermal effects in micro-systems related to actuation, thermoelastic damping, Joule heating, and the use of thermal expansion for measuring the mechanical properties of micro-structures. 
• Investigated a two-dimensional model of the thermoelastic dynamic response of temperature-gradient actuators.  
• To demonstrate the feasibility of the temperature-gradient thermoelastic actuator, I designed and fabricated a tilting micro-mirror device which achieved a periodic angular deflection of ±8.5° at 9.5 kHz, while driven by a 1.5 Volt source. 
• I analyzed the thermoelastic damping and found that native-oxide layer induces thermoelastic damping in Single Crystalline Silicon SCS axial micro-resonators.
